housekeeping: Fix systemd OOM notifications

note.body:
Yes, you're right. I was very vague here and not making much sense if I read back now :P

It's just that this `systemd1.Scope` `Result` property changes should be emitted via the standard DBus signal already, without using explicit `Subscribe()`. So then the question is why we need it here?

`Result` is the only property not explicitly annotated with `org.freedesktop.DBus.Property.EmitsChangedSignal`, so then it should just default to `true`.

target_title: housekeeping: Fix systemd OOM notifications

note.body: Maybe I'm missing something, but I wouldn't expect https://docs.gtk.org/gio/method.DBusConnection.signal_subscribe.html to do that because it's a general purpose method to subscribe to D-Bus signals of any bus, whereas `org.freedesktop.systemd1.Manager.Subscribe` must be called specifically to make the systemd bus (`/org/freedesktop/systemd1`) send out signals.

target_title: Magnifier zoom factor too high

note.body:
> this is true but it also isn't a real problem for the zoom levels people actually use at 1080p or even at 4K.

The 11" 4K panel in my laptop makes me think that we cannot make assumptions about the form factor or physical screen sizes people use. Ideally we should make things just as pleasant to use regardless of the zoom levels involved.

target_title: Magnifier zoom factor too high

note.body: Never mind, GNOME Shell already does nearest neighbor too, I was just looking at anti-aliased text in the first place.

target_title: Magnifier zoom factor too high

note.body: Let's stay on topic of how to increment zoom levels with a shortcut. I fully agree that nearest neighbor might look much better at integer zoom levels, but we don't control that here.

target_title: Magnifier zoom factor too high

note.body: For the zooming in to get less effective as it gets larger is actually just fine behavior for this in practice for other operating systems. Zoom scaling isn't amplitude.

target_title: Magnifier zoom factor too high

note.body:
> Pixels are linear

Yes, but our perception of zoom is not. You could argue that voltage on your speakers can be increased linearly, but our ears also don't respond linearly to sound amplitude, so we don't change output amplitude linearly with sound levels either. Same with screen brightness.

What we should certainly not do is weird rounding. The slightly rounded exponential 1.25^N scale of
```
1, 1.25, 1.5, 1.75, 2, 2.5, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, 15, 20
```
looks good.

But right now using the shortcut also doesn't show you the actual zoom level, which is another point that should be addressed with something like a pop-up number that disappears.

target_title: Magnifier zoom factor too high

note.body: Windows, if you turn off the smoothing setting, does nearest neighbor exact pixel grids every four increments when at a multiple of 100% and that works good. The other three increments seem to be an approximation although I'm not exactly sure how it's actually done.

target_title: Magnifier zoom factor too high

note.body:
> nearest neighbor zoom

Is not really related to the issue here. In fact, for this issue, if you want exact pixel grids, you would want to use 100%, 200%, 300%, etc. Right now that still looks blurry, but that's because of how Shell zooms.

target_title: Magnifier zoom factor too high

note.body: About "at high zoom levels it is more excruciatingly slow to make a significant increase in perceived size" -- this is true but it also isn't a real problem for the zoom levels people actually use at 1080p or even at 4K. I guess it could be a potential problem for the future on 8K+ displays but even then, we'd still want to have linear nearest neighbor zoom as an option for people.

target_title: Magnifier zoom factor too high

note.body: I can't disagree strongly enough with the whole idea of exponential or logarithmic scaling because like I said 3 years ago, pixels are linear. Windows has this solved with letting you zoom in linear increments, which I always set to 25%. This one accessibility issue forced me to switch from Gnome to KDE so that's the only reason it isn't affecting me anymore.

target_title: Setting org.gnome.desktop.datetime automatic-timezone to true seems to have no effect

note.body:
This looks like a shortcoming of the Mozilla Location Services geoclue retirement. I can reproduce the issue but am able to workaround it by using Google Location Services.

Long story short, changing the gsetting should cause `GsdTimezoneMonitor` to consult Geoclue2 for a location, but ever since MLS were shutdown the settings-daemon plugin seem to fail silently for me.

The call in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-settings-daemon/-/blob/master/plugins/datetime/gsd-timezone-monitor.c#L346 fails silently, and the geoclue service logs ` Failed to query location: Query location SOUP error: Not Found`. I also couldn't get [geoclue2/demo/where-am-i](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/geoclue/geoclue/-/blob/master/demo/where-am-i.c) to work.

**To workaround this**, I built geoclue from the source passing the `default-wifi-url` build option to `https://www.googleapis.com/geolocation/v1/geolocate?key=$GOOGLE_API_KEY` and everything else started to work (changing timezone in Settings updates the system and the settings UI itself, throws a notification, etc...).

Adding context to this issue.  The reporter has the following lines set to the service getting OOM killed:

MemoryHigh=18M

Memory cgroup out of memory: Killed process 1255400 (autoColor) total-vm:10680kB

target_title: Move input configuration to accountsservice

note.body:
This is basically done nowadays:

- GNOME Shell will use the accountsservice information for keyboard layouts in GDM mode
- Settings uses libaccountservice to set up the info
- GNOME Settings Daemon is no longer involved with any of this
- GDM will happily show layout info coming from accountsservice

Further questions (e.g. whether we should go all in with accountsservice being the sole store for this data, in addition to user settings) are better addressed in other issues in other components.

target_title: pinephonepro has a minimum brightness value of 0

note.body: A change like that sounds like it would affect old devices with not too many brightness levels, and increase the base power consumption in those if we ditch the minimum backlight brightness possible. Ideally, we'd get a consistent behavior from kernel drivers about what is the minimum brightness possible, but that ship sailed.

target_title: pinephonepro has a minimum brightness value of 0
pinephonepro has a minimum brightness value of 0

note.body:
That's because g-s-d _guesses_ the minimum brightness level supported by the backlight device. On devices with less than 100 steps, it just _assumes_ that step 0 is not turning the backlight off at all. However on the PPP, the driver reports only 51 steps and step 0 is still turning the backlight off.

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-settings-daemon/-/blob/master/plugins/power/gsd-backlight.c#L251

```
        /* If the interface has less than 100 possible values, and it is of type
         * raw, then assume that 0 does not turn off the backlight completely. */
        if (backlight->brightness_max < 99 &&
            g_strcmp0 (g_udev_device_get_sysfs_attr (backlight->udev_device, "type"), "raw") == 0)
                backlight->brightness_min = 0;
```

I'd hope that the proposal mentioned here (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-settings-daemon/-/merge_requests/331#note_1767581, `Clearly define that 0 is always min-brightness when setting the brightness`) would fix this dilemma.

target_title: Various gsd-power crashes in GDBusProxy

note.body:
> If they’re dispatched, that might result in a use-after-free of other structures which were finalised when you dropped your ref.

Why would the memory be free'ed if the pre-condition is that this was **not** the final ref?

target_title: Various gsd-power crashes in GDBusProxy

note.body:
> but that should be safe, right?

Nope. It’s only safe if the ref you’re dropping is guaranteed to be the final ref, as the signals are automatically disconnected on dispose. However, if the ref is *not* the final ref – e.g. if some other code still holds a ref to that proxy, perhaps some code in GDBus which is currently processing a message for the proxy – then the signal handlers remain connected and could be dispatched. If they’re dispatched, that might result in a use-after-free of other structures which were finalised when you dropped your ref.

tl;dr: If your code holds a reference to an object which might potentially also have refs held on it by other parts of the code, such as D-Bus worker threads, you must always disconnect signal handlers before dropping the final ref in your code. Because otherwise your signal handlers may be called after you think they won’t ever be called again.

target_title: Screen not turning off after locking (Meta+L or automatic timeout)

note.body:
More clues!

Unplugging one of my two monitors (both connected over hdmi), only one of them triggers the problem.

My Dell U2717D monitor, if it's the only one connected, goes to sleep and stays off.

My Asus PB277, if it's the only one connected, will only stay off for a few seconds. I also saw these additional lines in the journal:
```
Nov 07 11:45:10 andrew-nuc gsd-power[15833]: Doing a state transition: normal
Nov 07 11:45:10 andrew-nuc gsd-power[15833]: TESTSUITE: Unblanked screen
```
Not sure why those didn't appear before.

Leads me to believe this is indeed something with the monitor, and possibly with its auto-input scanning, since I believe the Asus will auto-search for inputs but the Dell monitor will not.

Finally, I discovered that if I connect the Asus via Displayport instead of HDMI, it will stay powered down. Something about HDMI is part of the issue. Displayport is just kinda annoying for me because I have to use a USB-C dongle for that, but it works as a workaround for the time being.
